Jacob Marley (died 24 December, 1836) is a fictional character who appears in the Charles Dickens novel A Christmas Carol. In life, Marley was the business partner of Ebenezer Scrooge. Analysis. The life and afterlife of Jacob Marley is not detailed in A Christmas Carol. The reader has no idea exactly how Marley escaped with an arrangement for Scrooge's redemption. Even he himself appears uncertain as to how he is visible to Scrooge on this night, when he has followed him, invisible, on many and many a day

In A Christmas Carol, Marley is the first character mentioned in the first line of the story. Jacob Marley is said to have died seven years earlier on Christmas Eve (as the setting is Christmas Eve 1843, this would have made the date of his passing December 24, 1836). Visit our Character Biography Help to learn more. Jacob Marley was born in 1785. He was a banker, and an usurious moneylender. He worked at a counting house, with his business partner, Ebenezer Scrooge. Marley was disgusted by the poor, and praised workhouses
